title: Else & Else If (Multiple Paths)

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Runs when IF condition is false. Must come AFTER if. No condition needed! Acts as catch-all for everything else. Only ONE of if or else runs, never both.
Additional condition to check if previous if/else if was false. Can chain many else if blocks. Checks in order, stops at first true match!
Checks top to bottom, stops at first match! if (x > 10) before if (x > 50) means 60 matches first! Order conditions from specific to general.
In if/else if/else chain, ONLY ONE block executes. Once a match is found, rest are skipped. Different from multiple separate if statements!

challenge.instructions:
Create a BMI calculator with health categories!

1. Ask for weight in kg
2. Ask for height in meters
3. Calculate BMI: weight / (height * height)
4. Display BMI value
5. Categorize using else if:
   - BMI < 18.5: "Underweight"
   - BMI < 25: "Normal weight"
   - BMI < 30: "Overweight"
   - BMI >= 30: "Obese"
6. Display category and a health tip for each

Example:
Weight: 70 kg
Height: 1.75 m
BMI: 22.86
Category: Normal weight
Tip: Keep up the good work!
challenge.hint: BMI = weight / (height * height). Use else if chain: bmi < 18.5, bmi < 25, bmi < 30, else. Order matters! Check smaller values first. {value:F2} formats to 2 decimals.
commonStickingPoints: Wrong order: if (bmi < 30) before if (bmi < 25) catches all! A BMI of 22 is < 30, so matches first! Order from smallest to largest for ranges.
Multiple if vs else if: Separate if statements ALL check. if/else if chain stops at first match. Use else if when only one should run!
Forgetting else: if/else if without final else means nothing runs if all false! Add else as safety net: else { Console.WriteLine("Error"); }
Overlapping conditions: if (x > 10) else if (x > 5) - what about x=7? Matches second! Make sure conditions don't overlap unexpectedly.
